## The secret power of the ‚Äú+‚Äù in live, outlook or hotmail¬†addresses

Published by

Rene van Osnabrugge

on

[July 18, 2025](https://roadtoalm.com/2025/07/18/the-secret-power-of-the-in-live-outlook-or-hotmail-addresses/)

![](https://roadtoalm.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/07/oig2.nbocu_.jpeg?w=1024)

I‚Äôm always looking for small tricks that make a difference. And recently, I stumbled on something that felt a bit like discovering an old Swiss army knife I forgot I had. It‚Äôs built into Outlook.com (and works with @outlook.com, @live.com, and even old @hotmail.com addresses). I actually learned from it by someone using GMail (where it worked first üôÇ )

You can use the ‚Äúplus alias‚Äù trick to make your email address behave in a much smarter way‚Äîwithout setting up multiple accounts.

#### How it works

Say your regular email is:

`rene@live.com`

You can now use:

- `rene+spam@live.com`
- `rene+shops@live.com`
- `rene+newsletters@live.com`

They will all still land in your `rene@live.com` inbox. But to whoever is sending them, they look like different addresses.

This is built-in behavior. No settings, no hacks. Just works.

#### Why this is actually useful

At first, this sounds a bit like a gimmick. But once I started using it, I realized how practical it is:

- **Filtering spam**: You can create a rule that says: if the email was sent to `rene+spam@live.com`
, just throw it straight into the bin. No mercy.
- **Tracking signups**: I once signed up to a service using `rene+storeX@live.com`
. A few months later I started getting marketing emails from companies I‚Äôd never heard of. Easy conclusion: storeX sold my email. Good to know.
- **Inbox organization**: You can use `+newsletters@live.com`
for all your newsletter subscriptions. Then you auto-label them or move them to a folder. Keeps the main inbox clean.

#### A few caveats

Of course, there are always some limitations.

- Some websites are weird about email validation. Even though `+`
is totally valid in email addresses, some signup forms just don‚Äôt accept it. No idea why.
- You also can‚Äôt *send* from these addresses unless you go a step further and create real aliases. The plus addresses are just routing tricks, not separate identities.

#### Want to send from a different alias?

If you actually want to *send* emails from another address, you can go to your Microsoft account and set up a proper alias. It‚Äôs easy:

1. Go to [account.microsoft.com](https://account.microsoft.com/)
2. Click **Your Info > Manage how you sign in to Microsoft**
3. Add a new alias, like `rene.shops@outlook.com`
4. You can even set this alias as your default ‚ÄúFrom‚Äù address in Outlook

Takes a few minutes, and you suddenly have a clean way to separate personal, shopping, newsletter, or even side project mail traffic.
